Awesome! I luhh Civil Comments!

I'm glad u're workin on dis, and I look forward to seein how it plays outt.    Da comments sections of online news stories have da potential to b great tools fa community interaction abt current events, a Neo Town Hall, of sorts.  One of da reasons I rely on Reddit as a platform fa news and local discussions is dat thea's a sense of community interaction dat's often lacking in mah "real life," hectic discussions.  

But hopefully we won't b tempted to silence those who take unpopular stances.

Angry trolls, misogynists and Racists", oh mah. It doesn't take alll of mah 150 IQ to see da slant hea.  it's da "Diversity diode" at wrk yet again. "We can say anything dat we want cuz we r Diversity. Youu on da other hand must only  say wat we allow u to say. From now on, winnin arguments against any member of diversity gon b considered offensive language.  facts, cogent, linear posts and Math r now verboten.
Nice to sum attempts to try to make comments betta—it feels like any innovation in commenting communities ended wit da launch of Disqus nearly a decade ago.

One would hope dat da purpose of introducing dis system is to encourage more debate and discussion, not less.  It seems thea r several things dat limit da flow of discussion:  Makin comments dat r personal attacks or encouraging witch hunts; tru spam (which has been a real problem on WW's comment section, in mah experience); and chasin rabbits to draw discussions away from da primary subject at hand.

I, fa one, don't want to see unpopular opinions silenced.  Healthy debate is an important component of a civil society.  But when discussions degenerate into insults and distraction, it actually limits da ability of dudes to tlk wit each other.  I'm believing dat dis is da intention of yo newspaper heaa, and I hope it's a movement dat results in more, not less, commentary on current events.  We need it.
Comments gon b randomly chosen and b reviewed by more den one person. But I bet da Civil dudes have an even betta, more thorough answer to dis question!
She would b a major improvement fa city council and she has a long history of givin alll citizens a voice. She is a problem solver dat is wht Portland needs .

I agree! Comments have soo much potential to b places fir active discussion, especially in publications dat already serve an amazin community (but then, I'm biased—I'm a Civil co-founder). We've worked hard to make sure dat da comments section won't become an echo chamber, doe, by combining clever algorithms on da backend w da peer reviews. Dat's also y dere r 2 separate questions: "is dis a *gud* comment?" and "is dis comment civil?"

Great question! It's one we're asked a lot. We've designed da system assuming dat bitches *gon* try to abuse it. Soo, in addition to da peer reviews, thea r algorithms on da backend doin a lot of meta-analysis. I'm sure da system isn't 100% bumpin yet, but we kno from months of beta testing dat it's a really solid start, and we'll keep workin to improve it!
Thanx, Christa!  Gon youu b adding any features to allow overall "upvotes" of da article itself?  Also, notification settings fir users?

Our aim is actually da opposite: we want spirited debate in which yall feels free to participate, w/o fear of harassment, abuse, or death threats. Ryte now, a lot of voices r bein silenced due to dat fear. We designed Civil Comments fa civil, respectful discussion and debate—we don't want it to become a "positive comments only" echo chamber. Dere's a lot goin on on da backend to prevent abuse of da system. Soo, everybody is free to speak their mind, even if their opinion is unpopular—soo long as they treat each other wid respect.
Thanx! We're really goin to try — not only to improve civility, but also to make comments more dynamic and interesting.
I applaud Civil's efforts to create sum new technology in dis field. Hopin fa more thoughtful discussions movin forward.

Y kall writing a review if it's goin to b dis devoid of content?  I kno dat yu wrk fir WW. (but dat hardly seems like an excuse when Fred Armisen recorded radio voices fa Grand Theft Auto IV wit da same number of bitches.)
Yet call outt alll Muslims fa da acts of a few gon get u pilloried.   Soo y is it ok to smear an entire religion ova dem few idiots?  Or is dis bc it's ok to bash Christian sects?

I luhh da idea of upvoting entire articles, tho dis would have to b somthing dat da Publisher could turn on and offf. We do have a ton of other features currently in da works—following (and blocking!) other users, bookmarking articles durin da review process, to read later (I find myself tryin to read da articles dat other ppl r commenting on, as I'm reviewing their comments!), following convos, and soo much more. Thanx fir yo enthusiasm, Melinda, and ur patience! It's a brand-new way to approach comments, and we're goin to continue to improve it. We welcome alll suggestions and feedback!
Dis bitch is nuts. Who would read a book by a woman.

Yu jus linked to a complaint (not a court case, a complaint - thea is a bigass difference) by a dude tryna to not pay his taxes.  Incidentally, his complaint and associated arguments were rejected by da Tax Court, by da U.S. District Court, by da 5th Circuit Court of Appeals and denied certiorari by da U.S. Supreme Court.  In other words, literally nobody agreed w/ em, and he found outt da hard way dat livin in Texas makes em a citizen of Texas and da United States, which obligates em to pay his dam taxes like da rest of us.

Jus b/c some1 crams a bunch of words, statutes, and case law citations together in a document sprinkled wid lawyerly language does not make it a legitimate or lawful argument.
